affirming prior forecast; agree with @Morrell that we may see 1M by as early as the 29th, possibly driven by the Greek numbers alone or the December numbers alone. I'm not concerned that the numbers aren't there for 1M; rather, I view most risks to my forecast as being driven by reporting logistics. Risks too forecast (within the context of my tracking methodology and wherein I missed a few days of the numbers): • Lag in updating the numbers - though I would have expected a drop off in reporting over the Christmas holiday yet there wasn't one save for no change on  24 Dec from 23 Dec. • Further downward revisions as on 26 Dec. This is an outlier in my tracking but I am missing the numbers from 12 Dec - 16 Dec. I expect most revisions to be upward, but occasional over reporting or clerical error can't be dismissed. • Lag in reporting may be hiding a decrease in the number of recent arrivals. However: •  Dec daily needed to hit 1M has been trending down (based on the overall number reported which would include revisions to prior data); while •  Dec average daily arrivals has remained fairly steady and could push the overall to 1M even without any upward revisions of past data.

Few things to note from latest UNHCR data on http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php
The website currently reports 956,683 total by sea in 2015 
The Greece and Italy data is "last updated" as of December 16, 2015 (identified by moving cursor over graphic to get details).
The Spain and Malta data is "last updated" as of October 30, 2015.
There is a clear lag in data reporting.  Given how close this will be, even a lagging few thousand could make the difference
As other have commented, the question is worded "data available on UNHCR's Emergency Response Page for the Mediterranean as of 31 December 2015" -- so this is about data reported, rather than how many refugees will arrive by sea in 2015 given the delays in reporting data.  This is unfortunate.  A better approach would be for GJP officials to close the predictions on December 31, 2015, and then wait until the UNHCR releases its consolidated data covering all sea arrivals in 2015, which would likely be in early January 2016.  
Is there any chance the GJP will clarify the competition in this way?  If not, then the odds of <1M "reported" on the website on December 31, 2015 should be higher

OK just to get an idea of how volatile this is, here is an experiment I ran: 
- Say the distribution of arrivals mimics the data from the last 20 days (or 30, didn't matter much)
- Put the Greek arrival numbers from the last 20 days in a bag
- For the each remaining day, draw at random a number from the bag. Record it and put it back in the bag. 
- Sum those numbers up, and check whether they give an arrival number exceeding 1million.

We're seeing a sudden uptick in the daily arrival rates, and Italy seems active again (based on the sudden ~5000 that the UNHCR updated Italy's December number to). On top of that, ~30000  arrivals to Greece in the first 8 days. If the Greece rates stay steady this gives 3700*22 > 80000 arrivals yet to come. So there are three big questions here:
1) Is Italy seeing a major uptick in arrivals, or is this some sort of fluke. 
2) Will the Greek numbers hold steady? For example, if there is some fear that Turkey will clamp down on migration, refugees may be dashing madly to make it to Greece before that route closes. On the other hand, this may dissipate soon due to weather or the actual clamp-down (if it were to come).
3) Will the UNHCR folks take the Holiday season off and not update on, say Dec 30 and 31?  If the answers to the first two questions is yes, it may not matter what the answer to Q3 is.

It's going to be close no matter what so we're probably going to see a high avg. score on this one.  I'm looking at the numbers in three ways. The first deals with the number of refugees this month. So far (Dec 8th), there are just over 25,000, according to this report: http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php
It also says there are about 911,500, meaning that 88,500 more refugees need to arrive for a total of about 113,500 this month. If you take the current level of arrivals for about the first quarter of December as a constant, only 75,000 more refugees will arrive, meaning there will be less than one million by 13,500 extra refugees.
We must also consider that the number of refugees will continue to drop off as it gets colder and later into December. The other way of looking at it is difficult and I'm not a math person so someone please correct me if I'm wrong. It looks at the percentage increase of refugees from 2014 to 2015. 
August 2014-15: 291% increase
September 2014-15: 409% increase
October 2014-15: 857% increase
November 2014-15: 952% increase December 2014-15 would require a 1,152% increase to meet 114,000 for the month and make 1 million refugees. 
However, while the rate of change went up significantly from August to September to October (40.% and 109.5% respectively), it has decreased to an 11% increase from November to October. It would need to recover to 21% from November to December to make 1,152%. It's completely possible but does not seem likely given the current trend. Finally, We must also consider that the number of refugees will continue to drop off as it gets colder and later into December. In both 2014 and 2015, numbers dropped off significantly from October to November to December (and onward). 
In 2014 October to November, there was a 42% decrease in refugees. From November to December, there was a 32% decrease.
In 2015, there was a 36.5% decrease from October to November. This is only 5.5 percentage points away from last year for a rate of change of -13%. Continued, this would mean that December 2015 would see a drop off of 27.8% from November, meaning there will be only about 101,000 refugees--12,500 away from 1 million. To get those extra 12,500, the drop from November to December this year would have to be only ~19%.  However, all of this will be for naught if Angela Merkel decides to open her borders for Christmas.

This feels a little bit like numerology, so please take it all with a grain of salt:  Thanks to vox vox who provided a link to daily Greek data since October (see http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/49429), I fit them to a Hill equation (sigmoid saturating function). Here is the result: 
http://s2.postimg.org/cq44qmi6h/Europe_refugees_Greece_only.png

(Lowering million + to 30% from 43%) There's been some great analysis from folks on here, but I think I can present a different way of looking at things. Right now, we're up to approximately 850,000 and today is November 21st. There have been approximately 100,000 welcomed in November. However, as others have shown, the main country that's welcoming refugees right now is Greece. When we look at Greece's November number vs. "all" countries November number, let's call it a wash (104k for all countries, 100k for Greece). However, The last update for Greece was November 19th.  For the sake of quick mathematics, let's just say that November is two-thirds complete and that the November total is 100,000 -- even.  At this point, that means we have one third of November remaining and all of December. Let's assume that the number of refugees who make it to Greece in November will equal the same rate as the first two-thirds of November. That means, another 50,000 refugees to Greece by the end of November, which would bring the total to 900,000 with the whole of December remaining.  Let's also consider the rate for December staying the same for the rate of November. That would mean, we're looking at 1,050,000 refugees in total. We can be fairly positive that the rate for December won't be greater than the rate for November, so we're looking at a ceiling of 1,050,000. Now, the rub here is, do we think that the rate will stay high enough such that it will still stay above 1,000,000, by the year's end? To my mind, 50,000 isn't enough of a buffer for me to put my confidence in the "million + option." ~~ In looking at the rate decreasing, we could look at last year's (which seemed to really hurt some of our forecasts early on) or we could look at the recent decrease. That is, look at the decrease from October to November. If we assume that November finishes with 150,000, that means that from October to November, there would have been a total decrease of 70,000 (220,000 in October).  Of course, the rate decrease won't necessarily stay the same, but given that we're dealing with a 50,000-buffer, I'm more comfortable "investing" in the "between 710k and 1million" option, until I see the data begin to perform better than this quick math. ~~~~ Oh, one last thing -- I doubled back to GJ's FAQs --> https://www.gjopen.com/faq Q. What are the deadlines for the questions? When do events need to occur in order for them to count towards the resolution of the question? Time Zone: Unless otherwise specified, GJ will use Pacific Time to evaluate deadlines (e.g., if the forecasting question asks about an event occurring before 31 December 2015, the deadlines is 23:59:59 31 PT on 31 December 2015). “Before” vs “As Of”: When a question asks about a situation "as of" a certain date, the question and all answer options will generally remain open until the specified end date. The goal of these questions is to gauge how a situation will look at a certain point in time. For questions about events occurring "before" or "by" a certain date, the question and/or individual answer options will generally close as soon as an event has transpired prior to the specified end date. ~~~~~~ COMMENT: Meaning, at midnight in San Francisco on December 31st is what will be used to score this question UNLESS someone has got clarification that GJ plans to wait a couple of days after Dec 31st. Based on the wording, I would gather that they won't be extending beyond the deadline (i.e. the question wording is clear). That is, more or less, a no brainer. Take the extreme optimistic scenario: that 2015 scales seasonally exactly the same as 2014. I.e., Oct.2014/Nov2014=Oct.2015/Nov.2015. With this, the expected arrivals for Nov and Dec 2015 are 126508 and 86508, respectively, bringing annual total to 965082 - a mere 34919 off the 1M mark. 34919 is equivalent of only five Oct.2015 days. Now let's go back to see what are the chances of this extreme optimistic scenario: very low! Because the peak in 2014 was in Aug-Sep, whereas the peak in 2015 is, at the very minimum, Oct. (and could still be Nov.) Meaning that missing the 1M mark requires precipitous decline out of the blue and out of line with every piece of news out there.

Revising "710 to 1mil" to 98% from 75% (had been as high as 80%, previously) Just looking at the current UNHCR data and doing some very rough math: It's at 643K right now and October is two-thirds finished. So far this month (Oct), there've been about 118K. Let's just assume that it'll be the same rate for the final 11 days (or 1/3 of October). That equates to about 70K more to the total (but that's probably an overestimation given that the probably isn't linear and that it's actually probably starting to slow), which brings the subtotal at the end of October to about 710K.  To break through 1million, that would mean that Nov+Dec would have to be approximately 300K (combined). Given the previous drop-offs we see in Nov/Dec last year, and given that we can presume that the rate is not remaining constant (in an upward trajectory, but rather slowly trending down), it seems unlikely -- my current prediction would lead folks to believe that I think it's highly unlikely -- that we're going to see 300K in the final 60 days (Nov+Dec).
~ I intend to revisit this at the end of October to see if how close to 710K the total is at that point.

Looking at data from [1], there have been 487k arrivals by sea so far in 2015.  There are several ways of projecting this forward, from most conservative to least conservative
1. The number of arrivals for the rest of the year might be the same as last year.  This suggests an estimate of 533k or so.
2. The number of arrivals might continue to be about 4x those of last year, month-per month (this was true in August and September).  This suggests an estimate of 670k or so.
3. The number of arrivals might continue at about at the current daily rate (about 4k/day) for the rest of the year.  This suggests an estimate of 880k or so. I think 2 is the best method, but might slightly overestimate the number of new arrivals.  This sort of crisis usually gets the most attention precisely when it is at its peak, so it is usually a good bet that the crisis will decline (this is a form of reversion to the mean). [1] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php

This question seems deceptively easier, in that there are hard data with which to base one's forecast (but that probably just lures more folks in to make a prediction). I looked at one of the "more info" links [http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php ] and based my prediction off of last year's monthly data and this year's monthly data.  The link states that there have been approx 478,406 arrivals by seas in 2015 (so far). There is still a little over a week left in September and so it looks like September will eclipse August 2015, which means that we can expect the total number to be close to 500K by the end of September.  Given all the press about the matter and the motivating factors for those who would be leaving for Europe as refugees, it seems almost assured that there'll be more than 560,000 by year's end (the drop off from Sep 2014 to Oct 2014 was about 30% and so if we use that drop off from a projection for September of, oh, let's say 140, that adds another 100K, bringing the total to about 600K at the end of October. There's another 50% drop from Oct 2014 to Nov 2014, which would mean we'd add approx 50K, and then another 35K [approximately] (for December, based on the 25% drop from Nov 2014 to Dec 2014).  So, that leaves us with a grand total of... about 685K. Of course, as others have mentioned, we'd need to consider things like weather, but I also want to mention one other two-part factor: motivation and availability of refugees (i.e. number of people who could leave for Europe). There are the "pull/push" factors for the refugees of wanting to leave where they are, but we should consider the idea that those motivated to leave are doing so in droves and so we might want to consider with each new refugee to Europe, does that mean the people that are left behind are more likely or less likely to also leave and become a refugee?

Initial cut, primarily looking at http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php (resolution page, contains variety of information).   Looking at sea migrant/refugee arrivals in Europe over 2014 and 2015, two obvious things: lots more people in 2015, and there is a seasonality to sea arrivals.  Drop in sea arrivals during last quarter of the year may be due to other effects, perhaps conflict intensity, but would expect there to be a weather component - (eg. mistral, bora, sirocco winds). Haven't yet found monthly data for previous years. Thus far in 2015, there have been 449,421 sea arrivals.  I'm going to assume that is through Sept 20, not sure but the numbers were a bit lower in Sept 15 report.  If the last bit of Sept continues on the same pace as earlier, likely to be close to the August numbers => around 130,000 sea arrivals for Sept.  I can think of various reasonable ways to estimate the expected sea arrivals for the remainder of the year:  use last year's numbers, use last year's numbers increased to reflect mean monthly increase for 2015 vs 2014, use last year's numbers but use the highly increased rate seen in August, almost 4x the 2014 number, or project monthly numbers for remainder of year using same % of peak 2014 numbers as seen in corresponding month.   A result greater than 710,000 looks unlikely to me, but it is possible that we'll see drops in sea arrivals that keep the number below 560,000 for 2015. In addition to weather, conceivable that there will be a drop in sea arrivals due to increased awareness of deaths on that route.  Also possible that the crisis will continue to escalate, with corresponding increase in numbers.

Current data: Italy: 128,500 (thru 9/20).  Estimate: Year over year comparison indicates 2015 is at a slightly lower rate than 2014.  Italian arrivals are seasonal, falling off during the Oct. to Mar. winter months. The trip to Italy is also far longer than the shorter trip to the Greek Islands from Turkey.  Italian Estimate Sept. (last 10 days): 6,000, Oct. 14,000, Nov. 8,000, Dec. 6,000 for a 2015 total of 162,500. Current Data: Greece: 318,489 (thru 9/16). Estimate: 2014 showed a slight seasonal pattern with arrivals declining after Oct. 2015 shows a geometric increase, that will level off at some point, but when? The Greek Islands are very close to the Turkish mainland, and volumes are much higher than in Italy. Estimate: September: (last 14 days, same rate as 1st 16 days of Sept.): 76,000, Oct.: arbitrary guess, 210,000 (Sept. est. of 160,000 + 30% incr. of 50,000), Nov and Dec.: 105,000 each (50% of October base, for seasonal decline + 30% volume increase of 25,000 each month), for a total 2015 estimate of 814,500. Combined arrivals are 977,000, for a first estimate before adjusting for expected changes in the Greek arrivals.  Expect EU policy may reduce the flows over the next 3 1/2 months.
